channel.title: Additional Plugin: ChopTree
channel.description:
Just a suggestion for a new plugin to add to the server, [url=http://dev.bukkit.org/server-mods/choptree/]ChopTree[/url]. While using it on SSP, I found that it was incredibly useful. All the information you need is on the link, but basically, if you cut one log down, all logs above it, that are connected to it, are cut as well.
EDIT: Upon closer inspection, it seems that the plugin hasn't been updated in quite some time (about 10 months). However, I would still like a plugin like this to be added, so I'll be forking the source and modifying it to make it useable.
If you're interested, I've whipped up a plugin that achieves this.
https://github.com/Zymus/Lumberjack

item.title: Additional Plugin: ChopTree
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:13, topic:462795”][quote author=hat trix link=topic=566014.msg4162610#msg4162610 date=1353281813]

You could make it so it only works on log blocks that have no other logs AROUND them, so it wouldn’t work on a wall made of logs, only a single stack of logs.

only problem about that would be that it would leave the branches that are formed with normal trees.
[/quote]

No, just apply the logic to the actual log you chop, then do the rest like normal.[/quote]

But then you have the 2x2 Jungle trees, and it would no longer work.

The other problem is if you have logs as a support beam, without directly touching other blocks, like
[tt]
A = Air
W = Wood

W W W W W
A A W A A
A A W A A
A A W A A
A A W A A
[/tt]

All wood blocks would be destroyed, including what would be the second level floor, as (I don’t believe) there’s any way to tell whether or not a block was generated “naturally”.

EDIT: I think the most that I would be able to do is check if there’s a leaf block at the top-most point on the tree. Or perhaps that there’s a leaf block at the top of each trunk (for 2x2 trees)
